Understate: The claim understates the evolving stance of health authorities regarding COVID-19 vaccines for pregnant women. It fails to mention the updated guidance from the CDC in August urging all pregnant women to get the vaccine.
Falters at times: The claim falters by not providing a comprehensive and up-to-date overview of the recommendations from health authorities regarding COVID-19 vaccines for pregnant women.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient support as it does not provide specific evidence or data to back up the assertion that the World Health Organization warned pregnant women to avoid the COVID-19 vaccine.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption by implying that the World Health Organization's warning in January still holds true, without acknowledging the updated guidance from the CDC in August.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to acknowledge the alternative explanation provided by the CDC, which states that the benefits of receiving a COVID-19 vaccine during pregnancy outweigh the potential risks.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the CDC urged all pregnant women to get the COVID-19 vaccine in August, which is not mentioned in the claim.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the initial warning from the World Health Organization by stating that pregnant women should avoid the COVID-19 vaccine, without mentioning the specific circumstances under which vaccination may be recommended for pregnant women at high risk of exposure.
